page.title: 13The East Riding Dialect
page.content: Some of the oldest inhabitants of Garton,particularly farm-workers, still naturally speak a dialect. Younger villagers can understand it but the children have very little knowledge of it. As one might expect farm folk have had very little 'bewk-larnin' over the centuries.This has resulted in a language which has changed very little in the last 4 or 5 hundred years and has much in common with the English of a 1000 years ago.At that time the East Riding was heavily invaded by Norsemen particularly from Denmark.An analysis of the dialect shows few French or Latin words but many Danish. We interviewed 82 year old Mr W with a tape recorder.We found that he naturally spoke a dialect and knew and used words spoken by the Norsemen of a 1000 years ago.
